description:
Sapovirus Hu/Dresden/pJG-Sap01/DE is a member of the Sapovirus genus, which belongs to the Caliciviridae family of viruses. Sapoviruses are small, non-enveloped, single-stranded, positive-sense RNA viruses that are known to cause acute gastroenteritis in humans and various animal species.

The specific strain Sapovirus Hu/Dresden/pJG-Sap01/DE was isolated from a human stool sample collected in Dresden, Germany. Genetic analysis of this strain has revealed that it belongs to the Sapovirus genogroup I, which is one of the five recognized genogroups within the Sapovirus genus.

Sapoviruses, including Sapovirus Hu/Dresden/pJG-Sap01/DE, primarily infect the gastrointestinal tract and can cause symptoms such as diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and nausea. The virus is transmitted through the fecal-oral route, and outbreaks are often associated with contaminated food or water sources.

Continued research on the epidemiology, genetic diversity, and pathogenesis of Sapovirus Hu/Dresden/pJG-Sap01/DE and other Sapovirus strains is important for understanding their public health impact and developing effective prevention and control strategies.
